OOC: Damn I suck!
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: rAuq 
  To: nbwrp=
g@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, April 05, 2001 8:17 PM
  Subject: Re: =
Into the Fire


  OOC: This is a explaination. You don't have to read it un=
less you 
  want to be bored. =3DP (or interested, if you like physics and =
stuff.)

  The boulder would land first, but not because it weighs more, 
 =
 because the feather float, it catches air. If it couldn't catch air, and 
=
  therefore couldn't float, then they would both land at the same time. 
  =
Ever watch Bill Nye: Science Guy? Wait.... lemme think about 
  this.  Weig=
ht is mass multiplied by gravity, therefore force. Force 
  doesn't affect =
velocity. 
        The equation you would have needed to use to calculate h=
ow 
  fast the objects are traveling is Ep + Ek =3D Ep + Ek (Ek=3Dkinetic 
=
  energy, and Ep=3Dpotential energy). 
        Ek on the left side would ca=
ncel, because v=3D0 (v=3Dvelocity). The 
  Ep on the right side would also =
cancel out, since h=3D0 (h=3Dheight).       
        That leaves Ep=3DEk. E=
p=3Dmgh, and Ek=3D0.5mv^2. (the " ^ " sign 
  represents "to the power of")=
. 
        Then you'd have mgh=3D0.5mv^2. Mass cancels, making leaving 
  u=
s with gh=3D0.5v^2. 
  Thus, I conclude that mass doesn't affect how fast y=
ou fall, only 
  how high you are at the start.

  PS: weight is a force, i=
n newtons. Mass is usually in kilograms, or 
  pounds etc.



  On 5 Apr 20=
01, at 15:42, dcoburn wrote:

  > OOC: Hehe, rAuq, weight does effect how f=
ast you fall.  If you took a feather, and a boulder, and dropped them from =
the same height, which would land first?  The boulder, because it WEIGHS mo=
re.

 To: nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com

airodinamic :-)

  > 
  >   Prowl sees that he indeed w=
asn't gaining on this diving bot, it was
  >   just the lack of knowledge o=
f the person that was writing his posts
  >   that was making him think he =
was. He hears the command from Halucigen.
  >   The control bug was beginni=
ng to wear off, but it still had some
  >   effect.
  > 
  >   Prowl lands =
on the ground, seeing Iron Raptor walking toward
  >   Fireblade. He tilts =
his head. The beast side of him was curious in
  >   seeing another beast l=
ike it, as they wern't common at all. Forgetting
  >   about his 'orders', =
he walks off toward Iron Raptor, reaching her and
  >   sniffing at her pri=
vates, much like a dog does to get to know another
  >   dog.
  > 
  > 
  >=

 your weight has nothing to do with how fast you

on how big you are (in other words, bigger=3Dslower

istance) =3DP
